Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I stood in the voting booth, pen in hand, my ballot sealed in the envelope. The poll worker leaned over and pointed out a smudge on my signature. “Could you please re-sign this? It’s important for your vote to count,” she said gently. I nodded, but my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was a text from my stepdad: “Rough day. Can you call when you’re done?” I knew he’d been struggling lately, and Mom had asked me to check in more often, to be the glue holding us together. I wanted to be there for them, to show I cared, but the poll worker was waiting, and the line behind me was growing. I felt the weight of both roles pressing down—my family needed my support, but I also had to follow the rules here, to do my civic duty right. My hands trembled as I tried to focus, torn between the urge to rush out and call home, and the responsibility to make sure my vote would count.
